articles.headline: Strong Yen Fuels Rise in Japanese Takeovers
articles.snippet: The purchasing power of the yen has prompted some Japanese companies to go on global shopping sprees.
articles.abstract: The purchasing power of the yen has prompted some Japanese companies to go on global shopping sprees.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  The purchases pale in prestige compared with deals like Sony’s takeover of Columbia Pictures, or Mitsubishi’s purchase of the Rockefeller Center, both at the peak of Japan’s economic bubble in 1989.

articles.headline: Salmonella at Egg Farm Traced to 2008
articles.snippet: An Iowa farm received hundreds of positive results for salmonella in the two years before its eggs sickened more than 1,500 people, investigators said.
articles.abstract: An Iowa farm received hundreds of positive results for salmonella in the two years before its eggs sickened more than 1,500 people, investigators said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A major egg producer linked to an outbreak of salmonella that has sickened more than 1,500 people conducted tests as far back as 2008 that indicated the possible presence of the dangerous bacteria in its henhouses, according to records released on Tuesday by Congressional investigators.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and William Neuman

articles.headline: For Blacks, Progress in Happiness
articles.snippet: Economists found even though racial gaps had grown in some areas, black Americans made strides in happiness.
articles.abstract: Economists found even though racial gaps had grown in some areas, black Americans made strides in happiness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Set aside some prominent success stories, like the current occupant of the White House, and the last few decades have not been great ones for African-American progress.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Leaders Say Delaware Upset Damages Senate Hopes
articles.snippet: Christine O’Donnell, the dissident Republican who won the primary Tuesday, was seen by party leaders as a weaker candidate in the general election.
articles.abstract: Christine O’Donnell, the dissident Republican who won the primary Tuesday, was seen by party leaders as a weaker candidate in the general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Tea Party movement scored another victory on Tuesday, helping to propel a dissident Republican, Christine O’Donnell, to an upset win over Representative Michael N. Castle in the race for the United States Senate nomination in Delaware.

articles.headline: Amid Blight and Scavenging, ‘Old G.M.’ Plants Linger
articles.snippet: The General Motors bankruptcy gave birth to two different G.M.’s, and one of them is struggling in the shadow of the other.
articles.abstract: The General Motors bankruptcy gave birth to two different G.M.’s, and one of them is struggling in the shadow of the other.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich.  By day, hundreds of General Motors workers make pistons and other engine parts at a factory on this city’s east side. By night, gangs of thieves have repeatedly looted empty G.M. plants on the same property, and have twice fired shots at security guards.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: India’s Protests Are Cherished and Maligned
articles.snippet: Strikes known as bandhs can inflict huge economic losses, often to the working person in whose name they occur.
articles.abstract: Strikes known as bandhs can inflict huge economic losses, often to the working person in whose name they occur.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALCUTTA  This kaleidoscopic city of 15 million people stopped dead last Tuesday. Flights were canceled at the airport. The streets, ordinarily throbbing with traffic and humanity, were almost empty. And thousands of shopkeepers like Wazeed Khan shuttered their stores in observance of a familiar Indian ritual  the shutdown strike.

articles.headline: U.S. Debates Karzai’s Place in Fighting Corruption
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is debating whether to make Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai, a more central player in efforts to root out graft.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is debating whether to make Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai, a more central player in efforts to root out graft.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is debating whether to make Afghanistan’s president, Hamid Karzai, a more central player in efforts to root out corruption in his own government, including giving him more oversight of graft investigators and notifying him before any arrests, according to senior American officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Rod Nordland

articles.headline: 3 Women Claim Bias at Goldman
articles.snippet: Three former female employees, including two who held high-ranking executive positions, claim discrimination in pay and promotion.
articles.abstract: Three former female employees, including two who held high-ranking executive positions, claim discrimination in pay and promotion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three former female employees at Goldman Sachs sued the investment bank on Wednesday, contending that the firm discriminates systematically against women.
